title: 109_s1794
content: The Act titled "Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve Act of 2005" amends the Energy Policy and Conservation Act to establish a Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve. It includes definitions for gasoline and reserve, and outlines the establishment of the reserve. The Secretary will establish a Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve separate from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The Reserve will hold up to 40,000,000 barrels of gasoline and 7,500,000 barrels of jet fuel at strategically located sites within the U.S. operational within 2 years of enactment. The Secretary will establish a Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve separate from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, holding up to 40,000,000 barrels of gasoline and 7,500,000 barrels of jet fuel at strategic U.S. locations. The Secretary shall obtain Homeland Security's concurrence on security measures for the Reserve and has the authority to acquire, store, and sell gasoline and fuel as needed. The Secretary will establish a Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve holding up to 40,000,000 barrels of gasoline and 7,500,000 barrels of jet fuel at strategic U.S. locations. The Reserve will be maintained for quality, quantity, and operational capacity. The filling process should be completed by March 1, 2008, with the option for extensions if it causes an economic burden, requiring approval from Congress. The Secretary will establish a Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve holding up to 40,000,000 barrels of gasoline and 7,500,000 barrels of jet fuel at strategic U.S. locations. The Reserve will be maintained for quality, quantity, and operational capacity. The filling process should be completed by March 1, 2008, with the option for extensions if it causes an economic burden, requiring approval from Congress. SEC. 193. RELEASE OF GASOLINE AND FUEL. The Secretary will release gasoline or fuel from the Reserve only if there is a severe fuel supply disruption, as determined by the President or upon written request from a State Governor. The Secretary will release gasoline or fuel from the Reserve based on a written request from a State Governor, which must demonstrate a regional or statewide supply shortage, a substantial price increase, and potential adverse economic impact. The Secretary must agree with the Governor's findings and determine that the release would stabilize prices without harming the state's long-term economy. The Secretary will respond to requests for gasoline or fuel release from the Reserve within 5 days, either approving, denying, or requesting more information. Procedures for release will be established, ensuring prices are not suppressed below market trends. Eligibility criteria for entities requesting releases will be defined. The term "eligible entity" refers to a gasoline or fuel distributor. The Secretary can sell or exchange gasoline or fuel from the Reserve with eligible entities. The Secretary will evaluate the drawdown and sales procedures established for eligible entities. The Secretary will evaluate drawdown and sales procedures for eligible entities as per SEC. 194. The Secretary must submit a plan to Congress and the President within 45 days of enactment, detailing the acquisition of storage facilities, gasoline, and fuel for the Reserve, along with estimated costs and efforts to minimize future drawdowns. Actions to maintain the quality of gasoline and fuel in the Reserve must also be included. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 90 days on the feasibility of creating a natural gas and diesel reserve similar to the existing Reserve. SEC. 195. STRATEGIC GASOLINE AND FUEL RESERVE FUND. Establishment of the Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve Fund in the Treasury of the United States, consisting of appropriated amounts and interest earned. Transfers to the Fund include amounts collected from the sale of gasoline or fuel. Expenditures from the Fund can be made without further appropriation upon request by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Treasury transfers necessary amounts from the Fund to the Secretary for activities under this part. The Secretary of the Treasury invests the Fund in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Investments can be made through original issue or purchase of outstanding obligations at market price. The Secretary of the Treasury can sell obligations acquired by the Fund at market price. Interest and proceeds from obligations in the Fund are credited to it. Amounts required to be transferred to the Fund are done monthly based on estimates by the Secretary of the Treasury, with adjustments made for any discrepancies in prior estimates. SEC. 196 authorizes appropriations for carrying out the provisions, while SEC. 3 makes conforming amendments to the Energy Policy and Conservation Act. Sec. 191-199 cover definitions, establishment, release of gasoline and fuel, reports, Strategic Gasoline and Fuel Reserve Fund, authorization of appropriations, and expiration. SEC. 196 authorizes appropriations for carrying out the provisions.
